DoubleWeightingStatement: Transmedia Television (approximately 94,000 words) was the first examination of audience attitudes towards the television industry’s development of transmedia texts and distribution platforms. It argued that audience perceptions of ‘television’ are both changed and reinforced by transmedia practices, requiring a shift in the definition of television. Extensive primary audience research over three years involved collecting 118 questionnaires and 52 diaries (completed for between 8 and 24 weeks) and 11 focus groups, resulting in a large dataset. The constantly changing nature of the television industry’s transmedia practices made the research subject particularly complex, an issue explicitly engaged with in the book.

EnglishAbstract: This is the first reconstruction of Paolo Grassi’s work as sovrintendente (general manager) of La Scala, Italy’s largest music institution and one of the international giants of opera production, in the period 1972-76. Based on research in La Scala’s Archivio Storico and Archivio di Deposito, the essay analyses the strategies mobilised by Grassi in the social, political, artistic, and media spheres to transform the traditional institution into a public music infrastructure capable of greater levels of production and collaborations with other cultural industries, open to new repertoires and genres of music and musical theatre, and accessible by the whole community.

Branding Television
DoubleWeightingStatement: Branding Television (approximately 90,000 words) is the first sustained critical analysis of the adoption of branding by the US and UK television industries. The book offers a model of television branding across three interrelated areas - corporate, channel/service, and programme - and argues that branding has an economic and cultural function in attempting to manage the production and reception of television. Based on five years of archival research and interviews, the book traces the development of branding since the mid-1980s across case studies from commercial, public service, network and cable/satellite television, including NBC, HBO, BBC, Channel 4, UKTV and Sky.

Captured by Women
AdditionalInformation:
Captured by Women is a one-hour documentary in four parts that focuses on film footage by two British women in the 1930s, in the film collections of the Pitt Rivers Museum. The original footage on which the documentary is based, by Beatrice Blackwood in Papua New Guinea (1936–7) and Ursula Graham Bower in Manipur, India (1939), is also available on this website.

Captured by Women was produced by the anthropologist and filmmaker Alison Kahn at The Oxford Academy of Documentary Film, in collaboration with the Pitt Rivers Museum, and with the help of a grant from UK Film Council via Screen South. As part of the project, Alison Kahn interviewed experts and relations of the filmmakers, and the film narrates the lives of the women as well as investigating their motivations in making these films.

The film uses the notion of magical transformation as a part of cultural translation through film to lead the viewer from the Pitt Rivers Museum’s displays and the objects collected by both women, to their photographs, and finally the original film footage. This one-hour documentary has been filmed on HD for a cinematic release and incorporates the pixilation method of rapid D-SLR photography that animates the objects discussed. The experience of watching the original 16mm film with the sound of projection, that would have been the only aural accompaniment to the silent film footage, is combined with the presentation of scenes and sound effects made with current digital technology.

Title: Miradas insumisas: gays y lesbianas en el cine
EnglishAbstract: Spanish. Miradas insumisas (which can be translated as Rebellious looks) is a volume about the intersections between gay experience and film. The volume's main thesis is that subjects looking at film (as audiences) or making films (as artists) have to adapt personal experience of homosexuality to what is allowed in a given historical context or to the conventions of filmmaking. Special attention is paid to  the diversity of strategies arising from a diversity of contexts  (censorship, studio system, avantgarde, art film, gay cinema, etc)  used by artists to convey their experience.

Title: Struttura e modelli narrativi nell'ultimo Moretti
EnglishAbstract: Italian language. This chapter is included in the Marsilio volume published in 2012 to accompany a  retrospective of Moretti’s work hosted by the Mostra del Nuovo Cinema di Pesaro (Italy). The piece provides a detailed analysis of the narrative in Moretti’s three most recent feature films: The Son’s Room, The Caiman and Habemus Papam – all of which touch on controversial subject matter. My analysis highlights dense, narrative structures, carefully developed at screenwriting stage and finalized in editing. The methodology adopted embraces quantitative and qualitative analysis of story, narrative threads, patterns and techniques, character arcs and aspects of the mise-en-scène.

Title: Paranoid Androids.  Per una pragmatica teorica del film intaliano de genere
EnglishAbstract: Italian. This chapter proposes a theoretical approach to the study of genres in contemporary Italian cinema. I apply a specific perspective derived from Rick Altman’s seminal pragmatic approach to the study of film genres as an alternative to more traditional models that tend to see genres as pre-coded texts in terms of themes, iconography and audience expectations. The pragmatic approach takes account of multiple factors including production and distribution systems; societal and cultural elements; and reception trends. This chapter demonstrates how a general awareness of  these factors among contemporary Italian filmmakers has accompanied a revival of genres in recent production output.

EnglishAbstract: Italian.The volume focuses on the current debate on the role of intellectuals, culture, mass media and cinema during the Fascist regime in Italy. Zagarrio questions the ideological bias that, in recent years, called for an explicit “revisionist” take on fascist culture through scholarly studies, TV programmes and drama series, and feature films. The book traces systematically for the first time the genealogy of this “revised” media representation of the cultural politics of fascism from the 1970s to the 2000s, with particular emphasis on the film industry in the 1930s and a number of individual filmmakers’ and thematic case studies.

Title: L’immagine del fascismo. La re-visione del cinema e dei media nel regime
EnglishAbstract: Italian. The volume tracks the stylistic evolution of Italian cinema from post-war Neorealism to the present through close analysis of mise-en-scène in a number of relevant films – from The Earth Trembles, Bitter Rice and Voyage to Italy to La dolce vita, The Leopard, We All Loved Each Other So Much, Dario Argento’s horror films and My Mother’s Smile among many others. Zagarrio approaches each case study through a detailed breakdown of its structural components, in many cases accompanied by shot-by-shot analyses. This methodology allows for a counter-reading of Italian cinema that sheds lights on wider contexts.

Frank Capra. Il cinema americano tra sogno e incubo
EnglishAbstract: Italian. Often identified as a populist maker of escapist fantasies for the Studio System this counter-reading casts Capra’s films in a new light, pointing out their profound pessimism: from social catastrophe (American Madness, 1932) to immigration (The Younger Generation, 1929), from suicide (The Way of the Strong, 1928) to social and family issues (Platinum Blonde, 1931; It Happened One Night, 1934). The adjective “capraesque” takes on a new meaning providing a worldview rooted in poverty, class struggle and the contradictions that are inherently part of the American values, myths, and ideals during the Great Depression.

Patience (After Sebald): A Walk Through the Rings of Saturn
AdditionalInformation:
Between 2010 and 2012 I worked as part of the core creative team, with director Grant Gee and producer Gareth Evans, making a feature film exploring W. G. Sebald’s novel The Rings of Saturn. Patience was conceived as a work of audio-visual literary criticism in the form of a film-essay and my critical interest in the relationship between essayistic forms in literature and cinema was germane to the project.
In collaboration with director and producer I compiled a list of interviewees, formulating the themes we wished to address, particularly the central idea of ‘pilgrimage’ as a contemporary practice of engaging with space and place. I originated the practical idea of a ‘Patience deck’ (a stack of postcard-sized reproductions of images from Sebald’s book), which we gave interviewees during filming, asking them to select images. This eased them into the filming process and provided Gee with material bringing together spoken contributions and images. Several key sequences were subsequently constructed around contributions elicited thus. I worked on ten of the fourteen filmed interviews.
 I collaborated on both the rough and fine cuts prior to the world premiere in Aldeburgh, January 2011. In 2010, I did public presentations with Gee of work-in-progress sequences from the film where we addressed the challenges of bringing Sebald’s book to the screen: at ‘Landscaping: Artists, Maps and Britain’ at the British Library in September and ‘Cine-City: Brighton Film Festival’ in November. I also did a solo presentation at the ‘Film Criticism in Dialogue’ symposium at the University of Kent in November 2010. Following the UK theatrical release in January 2012, I undertook joint and solo public presentations throughout the UK.

Title: Show of force: A cinema-séance of power and violence in Sumatra's plantation belt
Port Harcourt: Garden City
AdditionalInformation:
The main focus of the video pieces that constitute this submission is the informal waterside settlements that fringe Port Harcourt, home to 480,000 dwellers. In this project I set out to produce a series of films to be screened in the slum communities in which they were shot and to be used simultaneously in Amnesty International and Witness campaigns.
The series is a component of an avowedly activist practice-as-research in which both filming and screening in Port Harcourt’s slums are a means of investigating and increasing the capacity of these communities to mobilise. The practice develops an approach to filmmaking as political intervention predicated on an iterative and participatory process of production and projection. My films were screened to participants who became critical spectators of their own image and in turn actors and directors of future productions. Footage from these later phases was, in turn, screened back to them. The central research question at the heart of this process was how might these films inform the ways in which their subjects see themselves and imagine their futures?  The resources for self-representation embedded within the project, as well as the spaces of debate they create, develop the capacity of residents to wrest control of how their settlements are represented and how their city is planned.
In this connection the project deployed participatory media production to connect grassroots advocacy and planning efforts with international campaign networks and urban environment multilaterals, such as Amnesty International and UN-HABITAT. The collaborative process of production and the social spaces of exhibition, then, are at once objects and instruments of research: process and product together constitute these outputs. Film work and how film is put to work, the social labour of film production and the social event of its exhibition are central to the research.

Title: Jean-Luc Godard, Cinema Historian
DoubleWeightingStatement: This study of the multiple manifestations (videos, books, CDs) of Godard’s magnum opus, Histoire(s) du cinéma (1988-1999), is the culmination of fifteen years of research. Six months of intensive data collection in Paris were followed by extensive further archival investigation at the BL and BFI of the hundreds of films, books and artworks he cites. The book interrogates Godard’s monumental project in relation to his overall œuvre (150 works); to all relevant literature in English and French (dozens of monographs, hundreds of articles); to antecedent multimedia historians; and to the key thinkers on whom he draws (Péguy, Benjamin, Malraux, Braudel).

Title: Film Season Paradise Now! Essential French Avant-Garde Cinema 1890-2008
AdditionalInformation:
This major retrospective was undertaken for Tate Modern, and accompanied their Duchamp/Man Ray/Picabia exhibition in Spring 2008. It was co-curated by Witt, Professor Nicole Brenez (Université Paris 3 – Sorbonne Nouvelle), and Dr Michael Temple (Birkbeck), in association with Stuart Comer (Curator of Film, Tate Modern) and Laurent Mannoni and Pierre d’Amerval of the Cinémathèque française, Paris.

The overwhelming majority of written accounts of French avant-garde cinema rehearse the same periods, movements and filmmakers (Dada/Surrealism; the narrative avant-garde of the 1920s; the 1960s), misrepresenting the tradition as one of purely formal experimentation. Against this backdrop, the season set out to achieve the following research objectives: to construct a fresh history of the field through the pursuit of curation as a research practice; to demonstrate the diversity and vitality of this tradition by showcasing works from every decade; to make available numerous films that had never been shown in the UK (this was the case for over 80% of the 90 films screened); and to demonstrate the inseparability in the French context of an engagement by avant-garde filmmakers with political struggles and everyday experiences and an interrogation of the conventions and constrictions of mainstream cinema.

Witt’s work on the season included archival research; selecting prints at the Cinémathèque française; co-designing with Brenez and Temple the season’s fifteen-programme architecture; and setting out the research agenda behind the season in the introductory text (2,200 words) and the presentation of the fifteen programmes (4,600 words) that he co-authored with them for the 24-page booklet published by Tate Modern.

The event was extremely well attended, and audience feedback and press coverage (Financial Times, 17 March 2008; Libération, 13 March 2008) indicated that its central aim of reconfiguring the field through curation was successfully achieved.

Title: Organising images of futures-past: Remembering the Apollo moon landings

Title: The Act of Killing
AdditionalInformation:
I am credited as ‘producer’ on The Act of Killing, but the work grew out of intense and sustained collaborative research through the production company, Vision Machine (2001-2009). I was a founding member of the company, with the film’s director and co-director.
A key aspect of the collaboration was researching the historical and methodological implications of reenactment in documentary and the exchange between the methods of fiction and documentary production that came to deeply define The Act of Killing. My contribution to the film included taking a central role in conducting research, which resulted in numerous authored and co-authored papers (including chapters in such publications as Killer Images (Ten Brink ed. Wallflower/Columbia Press 2012), Fluid Screens/Expanded Cinema (Marchessault and Lord eds. University of Toronto Press, 2007) and Building Bridges (Ten Brink ed. Wallflower 2007).   I translated these research findings into a conceptual framework and innovative approach to filmmaking that significantly informed our production. This approach, which I term in my own research ‘archaeological performance’, is a performance-based historiography of political violence that draws extensively on historical reenactment and genre re-stagings.  Thus the production process is a research process, and the film is both research method and object.
Throughout the first six years of production I was intensely engaged with the film’s director and co-director as a creative consultant; an essential feature of our collaboration. This involved planning shoots, reviewing and feeding back on hundreds of hours of footage, working on and responding to edits, as well as engaging in the sustained debates around documentary ethics that attended the film’s production. This work also generated an archive of primary material that is of itself of value to researchers – it is the largest collection of AV materials on genocide in N Sumatra.

Title: Escravos
AdditionalInformation:
On the western fringes of the Niger Delta, the Escravos estuary opens onto the Atlantic: the site of a multi-billion dollar Gas-to-Liquid project, hundreds of well-heads and gas flares, and a region in which armed militancy, state security, international oil corporations and organised crime networks are as intertwined as the tangle of pipelines. In May 2009, Nigerian government forces attacked communities in the region with helicopter gunships and gunboats. Ostensibly an offensive aimed at up-rooting militant networks, one village was razed. 
ESCRAVOS comprises fragments of what I describe in other scholarly contexts as a ‘narrative geography’ of the western Delta. This approach is predicated on the notion that the political economy of the delta is graphically inscribed in its geography: ‘hidden in the order of space is a social order’ (Henri Lefebvre). The film sets out to frame the relationships that structure this space: the mud huts in the shadow of multi-billion dollar facilities, or found-frames the camera searches out and settles on, a blown out window in the last standing wall of a house, a doorway planted in the rubble. These critically composed images are an analysis of the delta’s economy of extraction and spectacular violence.
This collection of video studies and testimonies focuses on Joshua – a young builder; perhaps witness to a massacre – and his return to Okerenkoko after the incursion. In this sense, the series is not only research into film form as ‘narrative-geography’, but also an archive of primary materials on a significant episode of state-sponsored violence.
ESCRAVOS was conceived as a projection and performance piece originally staged at the Museum of London, the Dutch Art Institute and the Gerrit Rietveld Academie. It was projected with live voiceover translation and commentary. It has been subtitled for submission and intertitles have been added.

Title: Home Sweet Home [Film]
AdditionalInformation:
Home Sweet Home interrogates the social, political, economic and aesthetic vision that informs a radical urban regeneration scheme. It asks what insights this process offers on the current transformation of British society?  What new ideas of social inclusion and sustainable development are articulated and literally built into the fabric of the city by architecture, urban design and planning practice? What does belonging mean to the inhabitants of a modern city? And to whom does the city belong?
These questions are explored via engagement with the filmmaking process as a critical and creative mode of research - a practice that “overlaps with issues around knowledge production associated with the social sciences” (Wayne, 2008) - and with documentary as form. This practice is particularly well-equipped to decipher and render the complex process of shaping the physical and social urban Space in Time, and has the potential to deliver novel insights and lived and embodied knowledge  unique to this research method.
The film’s interrogative journey moves between two polarities – on one hand, the city and the forces at play in its transformation; on the other, the self, the individual, the citizen, the local filmmaker. It negotiates its own personal space, identity and belonging within this context. The multi-perspective architecture of its narrative structure takes issue with the ‘unique truth’ and the ‘objectivity’ of the ‘subject researcher’, experimenting with modes of narration capable of reflecting this multilayered reality. The participatory observational approach is also interrogated and challenged via this process and dialogues with other modes of representation, such as first-person narrative and archival footage.
Co-produced by Serge Lalou, Les film d'ici (France) and Sandra Whipham (UK) for ARTE France, Home Sweet Home premiered at Opencity Docs Fest (shortlisted for Time Out Best City Film award) and was shown at various film festivals, including Turin.

Title: Ghost Town [Interactive documentary]
AdditionalInformation:
Ghost Town is an interactive multi-platform database documentary (i-doc). Its conceptual architecture aims to provide a generative framework for developing new perspectives on urban experience. 
Drawing on archaeologist/artist Michael Shanks’ notion of “deep-mapping” and Jesse Shapins’ theory and practices around urban representation, the i-doc combines the extensive video archives created for my documentary film “Home Sweet Home” (over 200 hours), with other relevant data/archives, including content from the National Archives and the local Cuming Museum’s catalogue. It also includes open data about the area and user-generated content, to allow users to spatially explore the layers of memory, stories and media embedded within a single location. 
Engaging with one of modernity's ruins, the Heygate Estate in London,  the project proposes an immersive, interactive and participatory journey of discovery that brings in the participants at the heart of the process of urban and social transformation . It  provides an opportunity for users to critically engage with its traces, to develop into active citizens capable of connecting, understanding and engaging with the complex modern urban space we inhabit, and ultimately empowering them to promote change and play an active role in society. 
The i-doc engages with key questions about new forms of documentary storytelling and the shifting nature of authorial agency. In particular it focuses on three key points in digital storytelling: interactivity in narratives, multiple points-of-view, and the design of interfaces which function as narrative devices to communicate stories. Exploring the relationship between Narrative and Computational Structure, it experiments with different ways in which an interactive interface can deepen the narrative experience of, and customize the journey through, a story space. This initial chapter sets up the concept of story space and introduces the users to the idea of a story as navigated journey.

Title: La mise en scène de soi à la télévision : L’exemple du premier jeu télévisé sur ITV
VolumeTitle: Télévision: le moment expérimental : De l'invention à l'institution (1935-1955)
EnglishAbstract: ITV’s first ‘Double Your Money’ highlights the difficulties in establishing a standard performance style for ‘real people’ on television. A Goffmanian perspective identifies issues of: physical contact and body placement; modes of address; awareness of the absent audience at home; and the use of styles of self-performance imported from other media. Presenter Hughie Green’s own style is often challenged implicitly or explicitly by his ‘guests’, including one elderly man well accustomed to a different form of stage comedy. The many problems encountered in this one live half hour demonstrate that self-performance for TV is developed and acquired, not spontaneous.

Title: Far-flung Families in Film : The Diasporic Family in Contemporary European Cinema
DoubleWeightingStatement:
Far-Flung Families in Film represents the culmination of Berghahn’s two AHRC-funded research projects on migrant and diasporic cinema stretching back to 2005 (see: 
www.migrantcinema.net and www.farflungfamilies.net). Drawing on an extensive body of interdisciplinary scholarship in diaspora studies, anthropology, socio-historical research on family and migration, cultural memory studies and genre criticism, the monograph generates a complex conceptualisation of diasporic families in European cinema in relation to both Hollywood and Bollywood. In so doing, it opens up productive intersections between scholarly discourses on hegemonic Western and minoritarian film cultures and develops a novel theoretical framework for the investigation of transnational cinema.

Title: European Cinema in Motion : Migrant and Diasporic Film in Contemporary Europe
AdditionalInformation: The anthology European Cinema in Motion, co-edited by Daniela Berghahn and Claudia Sternberg, is the chief output of a two-year AHRC-funded Research Network (see: www.migrantcinema.net) for which Berghahn was Principal Investigator. Together with Sternberg, she conceived the book’s theoretical framework, commissioned and edited the chapters and co-authored the Introduction (pp. 1-11) and Chapter One (pp. 12-49), both of which theorise diasporic cinema in relation to the burgeoning field of transnational film studies. In ‘Coming of age in “the hood”’ (pp. 235-55), Berghahn examines how the diasporic youth film has reshaped the generic conventions of the teenpic and youth film.

Title: Ken Loach: The Politics of Film and Television
DoubleWeightingStatement: Hill's 125,000-word book on Ken Loach is the outcome of an extended period of research, beginning in 1999 when he was awarded an AHRB Small Research Grant to undertake preliminary viewings. Given the book’s emphasis upon the social, industrial and artistic contexts in which Loach’s work occurred, the research involved the collection and analysis of a considerable body of both written and audiovisual material. This included extensive use of primary sources, particularly at the BBC’s Written Archives where Hill not only examined a wide range of files but was the first to look at previously unopened files from the 1970s.

Title: 'Journal of British Cinema and Television' (volume 9, issue 3: 'Film in Britain in the New Millennium'), including J.Hill's co-authored 'Introduction' to the volume (pp.305-309) and J.Hill's article ''This is for the Batmans as well as the Vera Drakes': Economics, Culture and UK Government Film Production Policy in the 2000s' (pp.333-356)

Title: 'To Make You See' : Screenwriting, description and the ‛lens-based’ tradition

The Road: A Story of Life and Death
Publisher: Bungalow Town Productions / Crow Hill Films
AdditionalInformation:
The Road: A Story of Life and Death is a 75-minute documentary funded by the BBC and the Irish Film Board. It premiered at the BFI International London Film Festival in 2012 and was broadcast on BBC4 Storyville in 2013. It also received theatrical distribution and DVD release through Verve Pictures. The project was conceived, filmed and directed by Marc Isaacs. 

The film looks at the lives of various immigrants, from different generations and ethnic backgrounds, living along the A5 (a road stretching from London to the Welsh coast) and sets out to investigate, and shed light upon, the meaning of migration, place and identity for them. In so doing, the documentary examines some of the hidden aspects, and complexities, of ‘multicultural’ Britain by revealing the individual stories underpinning migration (whether forced or voluntary) and exploring the personal and psychological consequences of displacement, and a sense of ‘in-betweenness’, for those involved. 

In order to engage with the experiential dimensions of migration, the film also departs from traditional forms of television journalism and observational documentary in favour of more experimental - ‘participant observation’ - methods of documentary filming. This approach involved Isaacs developing relationships of trust and intimacy with the people in the film prior to shooting and then interacting with them during the actual making of the film. In this way, he was not only able to gain access to places that would normally remain hidden from view but also to uncover feelings and emotions that would otherwise be difficult to ‘document’. In this respect, his work involves the testing of new methods of documentary in order to generate new insights regarding the specific experiences of the migrant (as well as more general themes of belonging and isolation).

Title: On screenwriting outside the West
Hamedullah: The Road Home
AdditionalInformation: Hamedullah: The Road Home (2011) is a twenty-three minute documentary that follows an Afghan teenager, Hamedullah, in the UK and after his deportation to Afghanistan. The film grew out of Clayton’s work teaching video to young asylum-seekers in the UK (initially in association with Project Phakama and subsequently with the Children’s Society and Tavistock Clinic). Such children struggle to prove their refugee status and at 18 can be summarily deported from the UK. The UK Border Agency does not track these deportees but has historically claimed that they are safe. Clayton’s research involved an investigation into such claims through the long-term gathering of documentary evidence of what actually occurs in such a situation. With the help of local borough care teams, solicitors and refugee networks, she established contact with - and filmed - a number of unaccompanied teenagers awaiting asylum decisions and then documented the experiences of one particular deportee. This involved secretly filming Hamedullah’s deportation and providing him with a small camera that he was able to take back to Afghanistan where he, and later a new friend, shot material that was smuggled back to the UK on DVD. This material was then included in Clayton’s final film. In this regard, the film has not only involved an experimental approach to documentary filming, involving building trust and a collaborative relationship with a young (and frightened) deportee, but has also provided unique visual evidence of the effects of the UK government’s deportation policy. Partly for security reasons, and partly due to Clayton’s interest in ‘mythic’ story-telling structures, the film does, however, omit some of the ‘facts’ of Hamedullah’s specific case. This means that the film may be seen not only to document an individual’s actual experience but also to symbolise the position of deported young people more generally.

AdditionalInformation: Further Adventures of The Dialectic of Sex is the first sustained critical reflection on the feminist theorist Shulamith Firestone.  The volume was conceived, co-edited and introduced (pp. 1-8) by Mandy Merck and Stella Sandford.  Merck contributed the ‘Prologue: Shulamith Firestone and Sexual Difference’ (pp. 9-26) which locates Firestone’s unique analysis of ‘the sexual distinction’ within the fields of feminist, queer and psychoanalytic theory.  A further chapter by Merck, ‘Integration, Intersex and Firestone’s Dialectic’ (pp. 163-193), reconsiders her imbrication of race and gender in the light of the contemporary challenge to sexual norms  presented by the South African athlete Caster Semenya.

The Archive Trilogy: A collection of three radio plays written by A.Ganz ('Listening to the Generals' first broadcast on BBC Radio 4 on 15/04/2009; 'Nuclear Reactions' first broadcast on BBC Radio 4 on 15/06/2010; 'The Gestapo Minutes' first broadcast on BBC Radio 4 on 31/07/2013)
AdditionalInformation: Ganz’s Archive Trilogy consists of three 45-minute radio plays - Listening to the Generals, Nuclear Reactions  and The Gestapo Minutes (transmitted by the BBC between 2009 and 2013) – dealing with aspects of the historical experience of German Jews during and immediately after the Second World War. The plays rely heavily upon primary archival research - including the transcripts of German POWs recorded by refugees working for the British Secret Service (in the National Archives), the transcripts of German Nuclear Scientists bugged by the British at Farm Hall as they heard of the Hiroshima bomb (in the Library of Congress) and minutes of meetings between the Head of the Jewish Community and the Gestapo (in the StadtArchiv in Mainz) - as well as interviews with those involved in the creation and release of material (including Ganz’s own father, Peter Ganz, Fritz Lustig, Professor Soenke Neitzel then of the Johannes Gutenberg University, Mainz and Sir Michael Atiyah, FRS OM). The plays themselves combine historical record with personal narratives which, through the use of different artistic strategies, explore the complex processes of remembering and forgetting involved in the survival of trauma and passing on of cultural memory to the next generation. In this respect, Ganz’s work also involves an investigation into the possibilities and limitations of adapting and dramatising historical transcripts, and exploring different kinds of creative response to the gaps and silences that the historical record leaves (including the use of diegetic and non-diegetic music, unreliable narration, and the employment of radio journalist Robin Lustig to give voice to the archive).  Ganz has reflected upon aspects of this process in a paper for the Adaptation Studies Conference in Berlin (2010) and for History Workshop Online (‘On Speaking and Silence and the Refusal of Historical Accuracy’, http://www.historyworkshop.org.uk/on-speaking-and-silence-and-the-refusal-of-historical-accuracy/).

Title: Northern films for northern people
Burl Ives - Radio Documentary (Writer and Presenter)
AdditionalInformation:
This 30-minute radio documentary was commissioned by the BBC for Radio 4 to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the American folk singer, songwriter, actor and media figure’s birth. Originally broadcast on 11 June 2009, the documentary has since been repeated on BBC World Service to further wide and international listening audiences. 
In the programme Lee continues his exploration of popular media culture evident across his body of BBC radio documentaries. Lee’s is innovative media practice research that draws on archive sound material and original recorded interviews, insights from his published academic research, a certain performative presence and interest as a media and music ‘personality’, and also makes use of the sonic possibilities of radio as a media form. 
The documentary contains an analytical tracking of Ives's rise to fame from impoverished hobo to hosting radio shows with Bing Crosby and acting in Hollywood in the 1940s, through his support for Communist causes, subsequent blacklisting by the House Un-American Activities Committee and his desperate response of informing against his fellow folk musicians, notably Pete Seeger, in order to continue his career. 
By using archive recordings and conducting interviews with American folk singer Julie Felix, Lee’s programme builds a soundscape that illustrates both the influence of the career of one man, who is perhaps best remembered today for his songs for children, and the turbulent periods in American history that moulded him. 
Contemporary to the broadcast, Lee gave a keynote address at the University of Minnesota on the American Influence on the British Folk Revival of the 1950s, and the subject of politics and music is explored in his chapter ‘Like The Night: reception and reaction Dylan UK 1966’ in C.J. Sheehy and T. Swiss eds. Highway 61 Revisited: Bob Dylan’s Road from Minnesota to the World (University of Minnesota Press, 2009).

Title: From Manchester to the Mississippi - Radio Documentary (Writer and Presenter)
AdditionalInformation:
Commissioned for BBC Radio 4, Lee’s 30-minute documentary is about Granada Television’s 1964 outside broadcast of a Manchester performance by the historic Blues and Gospel Train UK tour by African-American musicians that year. The programme was first aired on 9 November 2009; it has been repeated several times, and extracts from the original interviews used extensively in subsequent radio popular music documentaries, most recently in October 2013 on BBC Radio 2’s Didn't It Rain: When The Blues Came To Britain.  
In the programme Lee continues his exploration of popular media culture evident across his body of BBC radio documentaries. Lee’s is innovative media practice research that draws on archive sound material and original recorded interviews, insights from his published academic research, a certain performative presence and interest as a media and music ‘personality’, and also makes use of the sonic possibilities of radio as a media form. 

Lee’s oral history technique blends a montage of interviews with participants who were at the original television recording, including fans, the producer Johnnie Hamp, and the tour manager. He also paints an aural landscape around the featured performances of some of the leading artists, including Muddy Waters and Sister Rosetta Tharpe. With his insight into the import of the event and analysis of why it became one of the most influential music television programmes of the 1960s, Lee also includes commentators such as British blues singer and presenter Paul Jones and American academic Gayle Wald to discuss the show’s post-concert legacy in relation to transatlantic popular music. 
Lee’s published work in the field includes his 2002 book Shake Rattle and Rain: Popular Music-Making in Manchester 1995-1995. He incorporated many of the musical elements of the show in an invited concert at the Lowry Theatre, Manchester with John Cooper-Clarke on 1 August 2009.

Title: Shakin' All Over: Popular Music and Disability (Corporealities: Discourses of Disability)
DoubleWeightingStatement: This AHRC-supported monograph brings together and extends two previously largely separate fields: popular music studies and disability studies. Based on research that began in 2006 with a call for papers for a special issue of Popular Music McKay proposed and edited on disability, it is the first single-author book-length study of the subjects. Chapters 2, 3, 4 and 5 each contain two major, discrete sections, any or all of which could have been submitted to journals for publication as articles, and in that form they would have counted as eight individual outputs.

Title: Lloyd Warner, premier mentor d'Erving Goffman
VolumeTitle: Erwing Goffman et l'ordre de l'interaction
EnglishAbstract: Drawing on hitherto unpublished interviews, personal documents and archival sources, this chapter tracks Goffman’s relationship with his first influential teacher at the University of Chicago, William Lloyd Warner (1898-1970). It shows how graduate student Goffman quickly absorbed Warner’s ideas while seeking to forge his own distinctive sociological perspective. Goffman continued to enjoy Warner’s support through to the completion of his 1953 PhD, in which his concept of the ‘interaction order’ was introduced. From 1949 onwards, however, Goffman’s engagement with Warner waned as his own sociological vision crystallized. Nevertheless, traces of that important intellectual apprenticeship are detectable in Goffman’s mature work.

The Silent Accomplice
Publisher: One Day Films Ltd, Todmorden, UK
AdditionalInformation:
The Silent Accomplice constitutes practice-as-research located within the frame of narrative independent film and world cinema. Produced through the production company One Day Films Ltd, the film is part of Knudsen’s ongoing critical and practical exploration of ideas through the media practice of filmmaking.

The work is an exploration of transcendental narrative strategies that can enhance our engagement with themes that go beyond psychology. How can one create narratives that engage with our participatory feelings rather than our self assertive emotions? This work challenges the hegemonic dominance of (variations of) the classical narrative within independent film. Developing story and narrative theories of Arthur Koestler, Paul Schrader, Patrick Hogan and Christopher Booker, Knudsen has examined existing practices within narrative film in such works as ‘Zen and the art of film narrative: towards a transcendental realism in film’ (Journal of Screenwriting, 1(2): 2010, 343-355), and constructed a rigorous link between theory and practice in developing the film. An original narrative approach challenges the function of dialogue, psychological motivation, story perspectives and the role of protagonists. The result is a narrative work whose silently-portrayed elliptical stories told from a uniquely non-human narrative perspective contribute significant new possibilities for telling cinematic stories in narrative film.

Premiered as one of only 15 international feature films in the official section of the Anchorage International Film Festival, USA, in December 2010, the premiere was accompanied by a keynote speech by Knudsen which articulated the research outcomes in the context of the digital revolution in film production and distribution and explored what its potential impact may be on film policy and production practices. 

The film is available to the general international public on DVD and as online streaming/downloads through a variety of vendors such as Amazon.com and Onedayfilms.com.

Title: Transcendental Realism in Documentary
VolumeTitle: Rethinking Documentary: New Perspectives and Practices

Title: Vainilla Chip
Publisher: One Day Films Limited, Todmorden, United Kingdom
AdditionalInformation:
Vainilla Chip constitutes practice-as-research located within the frame of independent documentary practice and world cinema. Produced through the production company One Day Films Ltd, the film is part of Knudsen’s ongoing critical and practical exploration of ideas through the media practice of filmmaking.

The work is an exploration of transcendental narrative strategies that can enhance our engagement with themes that go beyond the psychology of material observation. How can the narrative form of documentary be evolved to engage us subjectively and participatorally in actuality that goes beyond the material? This work challenges the hegemonic dominance of documentary as journalistically-driven sociological or anthropological observations of human materialistic conditions. Developing story and narrative theories from Arthur Koestler, Paul Schrader and Alan Rosenthal, as well as the documentary innovations of Sergei Dvortsevoy, Knudsen has examined existing practices within documentary film in such works as ‘Transcendental realism in documentary’ (in W. de Jong and T.R. Austin, eds., 2008. Rethinking the Documentary, Open University Press,108-120), and constructed a rigorous link between theory and practice in developing the film. An original narrative approach challenges the role of the spoken word and transcends the need for psychological motivation of character and narrative. By employing a meditative observational aesthetic, as well as a cyclical narrative structure, viewers are invited to engage spiritually with a subject without the usual recourse to objective knowledge or back stories.

Premiered at the Zinebi - International Documentary and Short Film Festival, Bilbao, Spain, in November 2009, the film has subsequently been part of a number of international presentations, including University of Colombia, UTAR Malaysia, EICTV, Cuba. The film is available to the general international public on DVD and as online streaming/downloads through a variety of outlets such as Vimeo.com and Onedayfilms.com.

DoubleWeightingStatement: My monograph The Birth of British Television qualifies as a double weighted item for the purposes of REF because of its extensive and original use of primary sources drawn from archives that are not open access, something that took several years of research. These archives include the BBC Written Archive Centre, the Post Office Archive and various newspapers that are un-indexed and available only on microfilm. These sources were interwoven and analysed for use in my book, where they underpinned my critical exploration of the changing expectations of television in the earliest years of the medium.

EnglishAbstract:
This chapter explores the relationship between British television and public service broadcasting, with particular reference to the distinctiveness of its approach compared to other European nations. It examines how each channel has served a different purpose in this regard, while it argues that it was the creation of BBC2 that signposted the future direction for British television as a medium that emphasised plurality.

THESOUTH WALES ARGUSAND CULTURAL REPRESENTATIONS OF GWENT
AdditionalInformation: This paper arose and was further developed from post-graduate research (PhD 2006). The overall aim of the research was to critically engage and assess how the South Wales Argus, a local/regional newspaper in Newport, Gwent, South Wales reproduces the ‘idea’ of Gwent through the cultural production of representations in local news discourse. The research was mainly conducted by two separate methods of analysis. The significance of the research is that it argues that cultural representations presented as news within the South Wales Argus are effectively ‘survival strategies’ that are produced to maintain a monopolistic market position in Gwent and that cultural representations are also the ideological product of the paper’s perceptions of a Gwent community. The paper explains how cultural representations are market strategies and that cultural representation is also a product of myth in the sense that Roland Barthes forwarded. It outlines the history of Gwent – changing its name to Monmouthshire in the 16th century and back to Gwent in 1974 – and outlines how the Argus plays upon cultural memory in a Welsh-historical context by actively pursuing and producing an ‘imagined geography’ as detailed in Edward Said’s 1998 work in Orientalism. This is based on the paper’s perception of the ‘Gwent’ community in spite of the fact that ‘Gwent’ as an actual geographical area today does not exist in any real form, and is equally an attempt to persuade the audience of a Gwent reality via cultural production. News Discourse Analysis of data and application of theoretical frameworks found that the language used and the way news was framed by the Argus was evidence of a manufactured construct based on myth.

Title: Journalism, Ethics and Society
AdditionalInformation:
This book primarily arose from my teaching interests in media ethics since 1995, particularly researching the work of two opposing intellectual schools of thought pivotal to philosophy and media ethics. Within this framework the book assessed the philosophical and cultural context on which journalism is based and researched the relationship between ‘individualism’ (Liberal Philosophy) and ‘communitarianism’ that prioritises the ‘collective community’. This led to a central research question, namely what is the social purpose of journalism? To explore the question effectively chapter one ‘History and Context: News and Newspapers’ reflects on the cultural history of journalism. Chapter two ‘Journalism’ then explores the ‘social purpose’ and ‘meaning’ of journalism and offers a definition in relation to a discourse on ethics. Chapter three assesses the influence of liberalism for framing the philosophical context of news and journalism and focuses on the Liberal notion of ‘individualism’ and assessed how this impacts on the ethics of news. Chapter four places the previous discussion in the context of media ethics and responsibilities and assessed ‘communitarianism’ – as opposed to Liberalism – by introducing a discussion on the US based Public Journalism idea. The final chapter explores the two concepts that are pivotal to journalism ethics, namely ‘truth’ and ‘objectivity’. The book calls for audience research normally associated with media and cultural studies and absent in media ethics, to more clearly assess the cultural effects of news on society within an ethical framework.

The book is currently being translated into Arabic by the King Saud Translation Centre, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia.

Title: Revisiting the Frankfurt School: Essays on Culture, Media and Theory
AdditionalInformation:
This book was developed because of the misleading representation of what is often referred to as the ‘Frankfurt School’ and therefore is a direct response to suspect research conducted mainly in British Media and Cultural Studies. Its rationale was to reassess the work of the ‘Frankfurt School’ who have been reduced to a small number of thinkers and provides a broader understanding of the works of writers who were closely aligned, loosely associated or on the margins of the institution known as the Frankfurt School to gain a more detailed understanding of their collective work. So for instance I’ve introduced Siegfried Kracauer, Erich Fromm, Leo Lowenthal and Hans Magnus Enzensberger along with Theodor Adorno, Max Horkheimer, Walter Benjamin, Herbert Marcuse and Jürgen Habermas; further to this Dallas Smythe is introduced by way of comparison to the works of Adorno. 

My chapter titled ‘Max Horkheimer: Issues concerning Liberalism and Culture’ attempts to show Max Horkheimer in a new light by discussing his insights on cultural development and social justice in relation to liberalism (and neo-liberalism) and culture. Overall Horkheimer wrote less than his colleagues and was side-lined to a large extent on discussions concerning culture and society with others in the field more prominent. However, this chapter attempts to correct that deficit because Horkheimer produced some interesting intellectual insights into the meaning of culture, and I provide documents to show this, not least from the much neglected Eclipse of Reason. The chapter shows how Horkheimer blended ‘pessimism’ and ‘suffering’ from Schopenheaur and ‘materialism’ from Marx to offer his unique form of cultural analysis, set against liberalism and authoritarianism and explains that like Marcuse, critical opposition to capitalism wasn’t completely negated under an oppressive form of domination that attempts to reduce the meaning of ‘individualism’ to matters of consumption rather than critique.

Title: Public Policy and Media Organisations
AdditionalInformation:
The research for this publication involved re-examining the political philosophers in respect of what is termed the ‘common’ good’, ‘well-being’, ‘good-life’ and ‘happiness’ and how such theoretical contexts underpin thinking in public policy that is meant to bring benefits to society. The cultural memory (or history of ideas) of Western philosophy (Plato, Aristotle, Marsilius of Padua, Thomas Aqiunas and many more) seep into contemporary narratives concerning the dissemination of public policy. The overall aim therefore was to assess the political and moral thinking behind government decision-making concerning public policy and further explore how news reports frame and represent public policy issues within a cultural context. In so doing the research explored how government and news media base thinking and representation on perceptions of community in the name of the ‘public interest’. 

Chapter one assesses the contribution of political philosophy, chapter two then assesses the ‘Big Society’ as public policy ideology and as a form of bureaucratic authority to shape society. Chapter three presents a discussion on news and the public interest and assesses a number of empirical examples of news representations of public policy issues. Chapter four to six are written by Dr Caroline Kamau, a Social Psychologist designed to assess key psychological processes between production and consumption of public policy

Title: Foucault's archaeology: science and transformation
Penser le multiple sans le concept: vers un intellect démocratique
EnglishAbstract: Michel Serres' apparently paradoxical proposal “to think multiplicity without the concept” reflects the project of a resistance to the temptations of reason, which always seem to fall back on some form of unity. The paper returns to Serres’ work on atomism in Lucretius, and on mathematical models in Leibniz. It then demonstrates that Serres advances an idea of thinking that involves exploring variations without assuming the priority of any one form or model. Such thinking requires great attentiveness to things and interdisciplinary learning, but also a certain naivety. These are the elements that Serres identifies as necessary for what he calls a ‘democratic intellect.’

Title: Liveness and Recording in the Media
Reaching Audiences: Distribution and Promotion of Alternative Moving Image

Film and Video Distribution Database
AdditionalInformation: The database contains information about film/video groups, promotional initiatives, distribution strategies, funding policy, and the history of avant-garde and political-campaigning moving image work in the UK – far more than could be contained or made coherent in a single narrative or fixed account. Control keywords orientate new users to the scope of the material held on the database, but users can also use their own search terms. In response to user searches, the FVDD produces a series of contingent histories based on hard evidence, whose documentary basis is immediately available to the user for further scrutiny. Across multiple searches, any individual compositional element will occupy different positions in the representational chain and its significance will shift accordingly. For historical study, this allows the polyvocalness of an event or record to be represented – showing its place in multiple causal lines – rather than being excluded at an earlier compositional stage. This makes it unique in the way it represents history and allows study of the multiple factors impacting on non-mainstream moving image distributors’ ability to operate effectively to ‘deliver’ a wider range of work to audiences. The database has been specifically designed to be expandable, and as more content is added to it from the 90gb offline archive, the FVDD will become an increasingly rich, useful and productive resource for users. In the past year, the database has been technically upgraded to allow remote multi-user inputting. This has enabled Knight to start recruiting a volunteer user group to help with uploading new content, but also (1) allows users to engage in research through the process of inputting, having self-selected material for uploading that is relevant to their own interests, and (2) develops long-term sustainability for the resource both in terms of content updating and the potential to pass on/share editorial oversight.

VolumeTitle: Maurizio Ambrosini, Giovanna Maina, Elena Marcheschi (eds.), I film in tasca. Videofonino, cinema e televisione
EnglishAbstract: This chapter is dedicated to the analysis of mobile pornography in its early days (before the 'mainstreaming' of smartphones), first of all through a survey on the relationship between technology and pornography, and a description of mobile porn as a 'disruptive innovation'. Then, notwithstanding the difficulties in finding information and data (due to the nature of the subject), I’ve tried to trace the historical development of pre-3G mobile porn in Europe and the USA, also outlining its distinctive features and describing its controversial relation to the mobile business in general.

Title: Piaceri Identitari e (Porno)Subculture
VolumeTitle: Il porno espanso. Dal cinema ai nuovi media
EnglishAbstract: In this chapter, I focused on a number of alternative pornographic websites owned by female models/webmasters, who tend to present themselves as 'sex lovers' with unconventional bodies, but also as self-conscious sex workers and activists. In particular, I investigated the 'pornographication' of identity through which the models/owners of these small porn enterprises build the erotic appeal of their home-made sexual representations. The case of Furry Girl – an unshaven vegan model, owner of four websites and of an online eco-sex store, and also author of two blogs – is a perfect example of this complete overlapping of life and porn.

Title: Le Grandi Manovre: Gli Anni Settanta Preparano il Porno
EnglishAbstract: After 1975, the increasing popularity of hard-core magazines in Italy has contributed to the growth of a specific cinematic audience with a 'penchant' for pornography. Italian 'popular' cinema of the time was characterized as well by a sexual 'escalation' that brought the limits of representation slightly beyond soft core. Through a historical survey of Italian hard core magazines and through the analysis of a few controversial movies, this article describes the process through which some peculiar characteristics of Italian 'erotic culture' of the 1970s have to some extent prepared the hard-core cinematic production of the following decade.

Title: Cine & Sex: Sessualizzazione dei Media e Cineromanzo tra gli Anni Sessanta e Settanta
EnglishAbstract: Through a survey of the sexualisation of Italian media and culture during the 1960s and 1970s and through the analysis of one case study – the photo-novel drawn from the sexy comedy Quante volte… quella notte (Mario Bava, 1971) – this article describes the Italian sexy cineromanzi of the 1970s, highlighting their particular relationship with contemporary exploitation movies and adult magazines, and also stressing their controversial historical links with similar experiences of the previous decades.

Title: On the border
Publisher: JMP Screenworks Online - peer reviewed journal vol 4
DoubleWeightingStatement: The development, production and editing of On the Border and the accompanying 2000 word statement with which the film was published in Screenworks volume 4 (2013) demanded an extended period of research, encompassing written records, visual materials, interviews, and several international shoots. The auto-ethnographic design of the project also required substantial time for reflection and reiteration – necessary to achieve a resolution of the personal, familial and representational issues involved in its creation, given its intimate subject matter, its engagement with mourning, and its aim of binding individual life stories into broader historical trajectories.
AdditionalInformation:
On the Border explores how memory and post-memory may be represented in auto/biographical film. It builds on the work of feminist visual artists eg Citron, Akerman and Spence to highlight the ways in which biography is a ‘dialogic making of the biographer and her subject’ (Radstone, 2006: 384).  
The film seeks to innovate within the biographical genre by eschewing a narrative of cause and effect in favour of a more associative form; for example, abrupt temporal dislocations between sequences are used to imply traces of the past in the present. The film foregrounds inter-subjective elements of biographical narration through the use of multiple voices where the speech shifts from first to third person and from speaker to speaker. Processes of identification and projection, usually only implicit in the genre, and particularly intense in a family context, are highlighted through this shifting point of view. Contrasting accounts/visions in different registers of Thynne’s grandfather’s death in action are counterpointed so as to evoke the subjective dimensions of traumatic historical events and their impact on memory and identity.
The concept of the border is used to invoke different levels of history, personal and public: the ways in which boundaries are both blurred and inscribed between family members, generations and siblings; the disputed and changing border between Finland and the USSR; the borderline between conscious and unconscious, ‘sanity’ and ‘madness’, ‘real’ and ‘imagined’. The film is published online with open access in Screenworks vol 4, 2013 where it is intended to be viewed alongside a 2000 word research statement.  To date presentations have been at international conferences including ‘Visible Evidence’ (Stockholm, 2013); FOHN (Helsinki, 2012); ‘Grievings’ (Ustron, Poland, 2012) as well as in public settings such as the Finnish Church in London (2013).  Thynne discusses the film in an interview for Re-frame  (2013).

Title: Ethics, politics and representation in 'Child of Mine', a television documentary on lesbian parenting
Playing a part: constructing a film biography of Claude Cahun and Marcel Moore
AdditionalInformation: An earlier article by Thynne, ‘Claude Cahun: an experimental biopic’ Journal of Media Practice 3 (2)  2002 discussed the script and early research for the film, Playing a Part, concluding with a general argument about practice-based research. The current essay reflects on the changing concept and actual process of dramatizing Cahun/Moore’s life and mutual art practice in the shoot and edit, including through mise-en-scene, the war archive and the creation of anti-naturalist, contemporary dance sequences in the later collaboration with Lea Anderson. The film is located in the specific context of other theoretical and creative work on the biographical genre.

Noise: a human history of sound and listening
AdditionalInformation:
As stated in its ‘Commissioning Guidelines’, the BBC required programmes in its ‘narrative history’ slot to display ‘creative and intellectual ambition’ and to demonstrate they would say ‘new things’ about their chosen subject. Noise accordingly aimed at a history of sound which, rather than focusing on acoustics, would place questions of culture, social relations, subjective experience and power at its centre, and to do so in the form of an original ‘grand narrative’, chronologically and geographically, by drawing on previously unconnected specialist studies in the fields of archaeology, architecture, ethnography, and social history. 

A wide range of secondary material, which cut across disciplines, was examined and synthesised, but primary sources were also used throughout. The series entailed extensive fieldwork, with claims about the acoustic properties of sites being tested: fifty-six locations in 10 countries were visited to explore the material evidence of past soundscapes. The research also involved identifying, locating, and then making novel use of recorded sound archives. The aim was to use ethnographic work not just as illustrative evidence of its own era, but to explore, through analogy, how sound might have been experienced in the deeper past. 

Rigour was ensured through a process of peer reviewing. Draft scripts being sent to for comments to relevant academic experts. Curators at the British Library Sound Archive and senior BBC editorial staff were also regularly consulted.

A broader intellectual context for each programme was provided through (a) links on the BBC website to related content, such as archives or specialist blogs written by curators, and (b) a book to accompany the series, which, though written with a broad, non-expert audience in mind, provided extra textual details in each chapter, a ‘Notes’ section referencing all sources, and an Introduction/Epilogue which stated more explicitly the series’ claims to originality and significance.

Title: Porn laid bare: gay men, pornography and bareback sex
Nothing that is not there
AdditionalInformation:
Nothing That is Not There was created for the A Room to View exhibition (February, 2011, New York City). It was later shown as a solo exhibition curated by The Art House (UK) during the Long Division arts and music festival in 2013. The NYC exhibition catalogue and a published review are included as part of this submission alongside materials from the British exhibition.
 
This project explores the narrative potential of digital media through the construction of an imperfect mirror, one which offers false narratives and impossible images.  It was driven by a desire to build a piece of digital media acting as more than an archive or another form of literal representation of a space.  It is site-specific, drawing not just upon the architecture of the room but, more importantly, on the (im)possibilities of the exhibition location. 
 
 Approaching the work, it is useful to consider a constellation of influences including Dante’s Hotel, work by Lynn Hershman Leeson, the literary work of Laurence Ferlinghetti and critical explorations of code produced by Casey Reas. These suggest a way of engaging with transient spaces in poetic, evocative and playful ways.  This piece builds on those ideas, producing a reflection of transient physical spaces and remembered places by using unstable media. 
 
Nothing That is Not There uses archival imagery, histories, ambient location-based sound and texts from writers whose work was written in, or otherwise engaged with, the location of the exhibition. The piece is emphatically not ‘about technology’ but about encouraging reflection and consideration of moments now largely lost to history. 
 
The project builds upon my earlier interactive rephotography where I created exhibitions and CD Roms that layered archival and contemporary materials to suggest multiple and intersecting narratives in Lee Miller’s WWII images (Traces of Lee Miller: Echoes from St. Malo).

Title: Drift
AdditionalInformation:
Drift was an interactive installation developed to inspire active and reflective engagement with digital media and its staging though the combination of rephotography and interactive design, incorporating and critiquing methods used in participatory art. It was designed as an exhibition that made space for active interaction and reflection by visitors, and that generated new knowledge and understanding about the ways interactive rephotography can operate. The gesturally organized rephotographic space produced was designed to provide a series of digital interventions in archival photography and to inspire viewers to share their own experiences. 
Interactive rephotography is often used to explore ghosts and hidden narratives in urban spaces. Spaces that have seen significant cultural change are often evocative and have inspired sustained interaction pieces – notably Norman Klein’s exploration of Los Angeles in “Bleeding Through: layers of Los Angeles 1920-1986” project, (2003). Drift, drawing on this tradition, uses interactive rephotography, but this time not triggered by a mouse on a computer but by the presence (and relative absence) of the viewer. The exhibition attempts to suggest ways to experience the impossible histories of spaces which no longer exist, or that have seen great change. In this instance, locations used had seen waves of Italian and Chinese immigrants occupy the same space as authors, filmmakers and other cultural producers. These locations, holding importance to more than one of the communities now present, were identified, rephotographed and exhibited, specifically by employing performative/embodied movements to trigger movement through historical narratives. The accompanying sound was constructed from interviews and ambient recordings taken from historically relevant places and their residents.
In sum, the combined practices, methods, and showings of Drift represent an attempt to explore the development of methodologies for creating expanded or iterative histories of, and with, visual media as interactive media.

Title: Coffee activism and the politics of fair trade and ethical consumption in the global north: political consumerism and cultural citizenship
Representing immigration detainees: the juxtaposition of image and sound in 'Border Country'
AdditionalInformation:
The submission ‘Representing Immigration Detainees: The Juxtaposition of Image and Sound in Border Country’ appeared in the thematic issue of FQS Vol 11, No 2 (2010): Visualising Migration and Social Division: Insights From Social Sciences and the Visual Arts. FQS is a peer-reviewed, multilingual, open-access online journal for qualitative research. 

This article discusses the four-year (2003-2007) research process towards Friend’s exhibition and publication Border Country (submitted for 2007 RAE). Border Country comprised a juxtaposition of photographs of immigration removal centre landscapes and interiors (devoid of people) with a fragmentary soundtrack of individual detainees’ oral testimonies.  

The submitted article on Border Country for REF 2013 constitutes new research. It provides a means for sociologists to understand how an artist develops a project: focusing in particular on the ethical, aesthetic and conceptual considerations involved in its editing, structure and final form. The article also explores Friend’s interview methodology and questions of power imbalance between artist and interviewee, critically significant in documentary practice. Whilst Friend published a short introductory essay on the Border Country exhibition in the accompanying publication, the new FQS article (9800 words) explores in detail for the first time how the work was made and through this makes new research claims. 

Eight photographs and five soundtracks are embedded within the online article;  these multimedia elements are regarded as essential to understanding the full import of the piece. 

It is therefore submitted as a PDF file (printed and included electronically) alongside audio clips embedded in the work (included separately as audio/image files). The full work, including all elements, may also be viewed at 
http://www.qualitative-research.net/index.php/fqs/article/view/1484

Title: The Home Front [exhibition]; AND The Home Front [book]
DoubleWeightingStatement:
The Home Front body of work is submitted as a double-weighted output: it comprises solo exhibition, monograph, and additional six images in a group exhibition. The monograph and solo exhibition have different edits and emphases. 
Research started in 2008; 1500 medium format colour images were taken over four years 2009-12; extensive liaison with photographic laboratories took place 2009-13; academic research, editing for solo exhibition and monograph, sequencing, liaison with curators, printers, publisher, book designer, essayist and foreword writer was undertaken in 2013. The work involved a very intensive period of critical interrogation, practice and production.
AdditionalInformation:
There is widespread emphasis in recent photographic art practice on ‘aftermath’ photography in war zones (Seawright’s Hidden[i], Norfolk’s Chronotopia[ii]) but little on the normalization of war in the UK – how militarization is ‘woven into the fabric of civic culture’[iii]. The Home Front explores Susan Sontag’s ‘perennial seductiveness of war’, but on the home front, where weapons are detached from their purpose, sanitized, and employed for entertainment – and to aid military recruitment. The Home Front images expose the culture of militarism embedded in public air shows, organized as leisure events both at RAF bases, and at seaside resorts.
 Spectators at air shows are manipulated by the spectacle and the heroic endeavours of pilots – away from the realities of war. Displays by WWII bomber aircraft, whilst arguably commemorative, are interwoven with contemporary fighters to lend legitimacy to contemporary wars. On the ground, tank rides and opportunities to handle weapons are on offer; the public space of the beach becomes temporarily ‘militarized’ and the sky is ‘anything but reassuring’ as Pyrs Gruffyd[iv] put it, writing of the loss of innocence of the sky following WWII. The Home Front photographs, simultaneously aesthetic and disturbing, alluring and uneasy, express these contradictions.
The project critically re-frames UK involvement in recent wars (Iraq and Afghanistan). It also develops my own engagement with war and the visual, evidenced by exhibitions/publications Homes and Gardens: Documenting the Invisible, (1996), No Place Like Home: Echoes from Kosovo (2001), and Border Country (2007). 
 
[i] Paul Seawright Hidden: Imperial War Museum, 2003
[ii] Simon Norfolk Chronotopia: Dewi Lewis Publishing, 2002
[iii] Jody Berland and Blake Fitzpatrick in TOPIA: Canadian Journal of Cultural Studies, Number 23-24: 9, Cultures of Militarization
[iv] Pyrs Gruffyd: Reach for the sky: The air and English cultural nationalism in Landscape Research 16 (2), 1991: 24

AdditionalInformation: SEQUENCE  is an experimental, peer-reviewed serial publication using a sequential edited-collection format. Each SEQUENCE begins with the publication of a key contribution to research in media, film or music on a particular theme. Scholarly responses, in both conventional and multimedia format, are then invited. Each evolving SEQUENCE  is then published in a variety of electronic viewing and reading formats, with the web version only the first in a series of digital iterations. ‘A Hatred So Intense’ was the inaugurating article for SEQUENCE 2, and extended debates about maternal representation, matriarchal genealogy, feminist cultural production, and classical and contemporary melodrama.

Title: Mutinies Wednesdays and Saturdays: carnivalesque comedy and the Marx brothers
Auteur machines? Auteurism and the DVD
Bonus Tracks: The making of 'Touching the film object' and 'Skipping ROPE (through Hitchcock’s joins)'
Publisher: Four videos and their transcripts about the practices of making film studies video essays
AdditionalInformation:
This work, published in ‘Film and Moving Image Studies: Re-Born Digital?’, a peer-reviewed collection of essays I commissioned for Issue 1 of Frames Cinema Journal (http://framescinemajournal.com/?issue=issue1), forms part of my experimental investigation into new digital forms of audiovisual film studies research. It consists of two online videos (Skipping ROPE (Through Hitchcock’s Joins) and Touching the Film Object) presented alongside versions of the same videos with added explanatory audio commentary tracks (transcripts are accessible on a linked webpage). 
The ‘original’ videos use quotations from existing film scholarship to explore the phenomenological and epistemological possibilities for theoretical and critical practices when these are performed synchronously with extracts from films using digital remix and compilation techniques. The ‘commentary’ videos offer further metatextual reflection on new videographic forms of film studies, pastiching commercial forms of documentary ‘infotainment’, which I have previously researched (C. Grant [2008], ‘Auteur machines? Auteurism and the DVD’, in Bennett and Brown [eds], Film and Television After DVD]), manifesting their essential ‘wordiness’ and tautological tendencies, and underscoring the argument of the work as a whole – which argues greater trust should be placed in less ‘verbal’ film scholarly forms. 
The videos have been played online 3724 times (by October 2013), screened in the 'Film Studies in Motion' programme curated by Volker Pantenburg and Kevin Lee for the International Oberhausen Short Film Festival, April-May, 2012, and shown at numerous academic workshops (including at the 2012 and 2013 Society for Cinema and Media Studies Conferences) and invited lectures, including my British Film Institute “Researchers’ Tale”, November 21, 2011, and my keynotes at the ‘Film and Moving Image Studies: Re-Born Digital?’ event at Filmbase, Dublin, April 19, 2013, and ‘The Audiovisual Essay’ conference at Goethe University, Frankfurt, November 23-24, 2013.
